name: MO5 E
keyboard: QWERTY/AZERTY depending models, full-stroke keyboard. Arrow keys, SHIFT, BASIC key, INS (insert), EFF (delete), ACC (accent), STOP, CNT (continue), CLEAR (cls), HOM (home), RESET button
sound: one channel, 5 octaves (7 octaves, 3 channels with the joystick extension)
ports: Light pen connector, Tape interface (1200 bauds), SCART (PAL or SECAM depending models) video connector (RGB + synchro + sound), Cartridge slot (Memo5), Expansion bus, Centronics interface, RF TV video output, 2 x joystick connectors (Atari standard)
description:
The Thomson MO5E was first revealed at the "Hannover Messe" (Germany) in april 1985. It was a big suprise for the french press as no-one ever heard of this system before. The MO5E ("E" presumably for Exportation) was reserved for Germany and more generaly for foreign markets. Quite surprising when you know that while Thomson was selling this system to Germans and other countries, French could only buy the first version of the MO5 with rubber keys, external power supply and no joystick connectors. Moreover, the MO5E with a light pen and a Quick Disk Drive was sold cheaper than the rubber-keys MO5 alone in France!!!

The MO5E is in fact a MO5 in a different case. The general look of this MO5 seems more "serious" than the original one with its big beige plastic case; closer anyway to the brand new systems that was released at that time (Commodore 128, Atari XE & ST line, etc.). The QWERTY keyboard is a real full-stroke one, with separated arrow & editing keys. The Memo5 cartridge slot is protected by a flipping plastic door, at the top of the case, just above the keyboard.

But the main differences are found elsewhere, when looking at the different connectors. First, two joystick connectors (Atari standard) are found at the front of the system, along with a big black reset button and a red power LED. This means that the MO5E has the "Music & Games" expansion built-in! Indeed, the original MO5 has no joystick connectors, you have to buy this expansion. It also add more music features to the system resulting in 4 voices and 7 octaves.

Looking at the back of the system, it is also quite different from the classic MO5. From left to right can be found a SCART female connector (not a SCART cord like MO5), RF TV video output which doesn't exist on the MO5, an expansion connector, a Centronics interface connector (not present on a MO5) and a the power cord meaning that the power supply unit is built-in the MO5E, which is also different from a MO5 which has a bulky external one. The on/off power button is placed on the left side of the system.

From a software point of view, both systems are identical. They both have the Microsoft Basic 1.0 (Level 5) found on the original MO5. The free RAM memory is also identical : 31008 bytes. In fact, the MO5E is completely compatible with the original MO5.

The MO5E didn't have great success abroad, and was, in fact, mainly sold in France to schools and border areas... Specific French models (with SECAM video output) were even produced as AZERTY models can be found.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> RIGHT SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Here, there are the same connectors found on all MO5 versions : light-pen connector (left) and tape interface (right).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TOP</strong></font><br><blockquote>MO5E systems were, at the origin, special MO5 versions dedicated to exportations (hence the "E"). So they had a QWERTY keyboard layout. But later, MO5E were also produced for the French market (and especially for education), with an AZERTY layout.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CARTRIDGE SLOT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the same cartridge slot found on all MO5 systems (MEMO5 format). But on the MO5E and MO5NR they are designed differently. The protective trap door pivots back to reveal the cartridge connector.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRONT CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote>These connectors are only found on the MO5E and MO4NR versions. They are Atari-standard joystick connectors. The big black button next to them is the new RESET button.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>1</b> - SCART connector<br> <b>2</b> - RF TV video output<br> <b>3</b> - Expansion connector<br> <b>4</b> - Centronics interface connector<br> <b>5</b> - Power cord (the power supply unit is built-in the MO5E)</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 84)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Laser 200, a Secam color micro-computer really very suprising''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil is an awesome manager"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZELAND AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mci.org.br" target="_blank">Museu da Computação e Informática - MCI</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. 1983 #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Hard disk version<br><br> "<font color="#666666">No matter how you look at it, KAYPRO is the best value you will see anawhere...</font>"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special offer including italian books<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Close-up of the previous advert showing the various cards of the Gemini 80-BUS system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #5 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SORD BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Graphics examples of the optional graphic card.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to the <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">PC Leaflets Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Laser 3000. For 5980F, play the double compatibility !"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><i>Texas Instruments home computer, simply unbeatable</i> <br><br> Notice that the man seems not to feel at ease with a computer keyboard and still doesn't use the right finger...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Charles da Silva</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> HEATHKIT CENTERS #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Guizzi (http://www.scribd.com/doc/938905/Micro-Sistemas)</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JUL 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 816/C VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 816/C version was a multi-user system featuring:<br> - Dual CPU (8085 + 8088) motherboard<br> - 384 KB of RAM, expandable to 1 MB<br> - 2 x 1.2 MB 8" F.D. drives<br> - 9 serial ports<br> - 3 to 16 users expansion<br><br> As the magazine 'computer Age' said, this system was almost twice as quick as an IBM-PC. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE FIRST M20 VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>This Olivetti ancestor, also called M20, was born in 1920...<br> To note the superb design all the young italian secretaries were in love of! <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Karl-Heinz  -  www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 84'S PARIS-DAKAR RACE</strong></font><br><blockquote>A KAYPRO IV IN ACTION SOMEWHERE IN AFRICA <br><br> 8 Kaypro IV and 2 Kaypro 10 were used by the doctors of the Paris-Dakar race 84's edition. The Kaypro IVs were used to store medical information about the 1000 participants. Power was provided by the Mercedes cars through the 12v cigarette lighters. The Kaypro 10s were kept in the "communication" plane during the day, and were used to centralize all the informations in the evening. At the end of the race, and after 12000 km of tracks, there were all running fine ! One of the Kaypro 10 is said to have been thrown out of the plane, mistaken with a common metallic tool box... And it still worked !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT. #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Part of a software advert<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> With NEC's PC-8800 personal computer, you don't have to ask yourself which comes first, the hardware or the software.<br> It's designed to be uncompromising in both areas. So you come first. In the office or at home.<br> The hardware gives you your choice of 8-bit or 16-bit processors, 5 1/4" or 8" disk drives and standard green or high resolution color monitor.<br> The software includes advanced, user friendly programs for all types of banking, accounting and business management. Plus free WordStar word processing, and MailMerge, Multiplan spread sheet, BASIC (two versions), and CP/M... </blockquote>

item.description: 5.25'' disk drive|||320 KB model|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> 5.25'' DISK DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> 320 KB model</strong><br><blockquote>This 5.25'' disk-drive offers a 320 KB capacity (40 tracks > 16 sectors > 256 bytes) and a built-in controller.</blockquote>

Disk Controller|||CD 90-351|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK CONTROLLER</strong></font><br><strong>> CD 90-351</strong><br><blockquote>This interface was used to connect a disk drive or a Quick Disc Drive (QDD) to a TO-7, TO-7/70, MO5 or MO6.</blockquote>
Joystick module||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> JOYSTICK MODULE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dual Atari compatible joysticks module</blockquote>

Music & Game Module|||CM 90-112|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MUSIC & GAME MODULE</strong></font><br><strong>> CM 90-112</strong><br><blockquote>This module offers two joystick connectors (Videopac joysticks can be used) and adds three channels to the TO-7  or MO-5 (resulting in a total of 4 voices). Sadly, these new sound features were scarcely used in games...</blockquote>

Ordi 94|||Joystick Interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORDI 94</strong></font><br><strong>> Joystick Interface</strong><br><blockquote>This interface enables Atari joysticks to be used with TO-7, TO-7/70 and MO5. It was sold by Ordivisuel under the name Ordi 94.</blockquote>
Printer PR-90 080||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTER PR-90 080</strong></font><br><blockquote>80 columns dot-matrix printer which was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-80</blockquote>

Printer PR-90 600||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTER PR-90 600</strong></font><br><blockquote>80-column 9-pin dot matrix printer. A rebadged version of the Seikosha SP-1000 with graphics capabilities</blockquote>

emulator.name: DCMO5 Gamer Edition
emulator.description: Easy to use emulator, to run MO5 games without knowing MO5 commands

emulator.name: DCMO6
emulator.description: Thomson MO5NR, Thomson MO6 and Olivetti Prodest PC128 emulator for PC

emulator.name: DCMOTO
emulator.description: Universal 8-bit Thomson emulator for Windows. Emulates Thomson MO5, MO5E, MO5NR, MO6, T9000, TO7/70, TO8, TO8D, TO9, TO9+ and Olivetti Prodest PC128  !

emulator.name: DCTO7 and DCTO8
emulator.description: Thomson T9000, TO7/70, TO8, TO8D emulator for Windows

emulator.name: TODC
emulator.description: No, you are not dreaming. This is a TO-7/70 emulator for the Dreamcast game system !

peripherals: Printer interface, Superimpose expansion, Quick Disk Drive expansion, Disk drives
